components.description:
A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a pig looking straight ahead. Depicted as a pink face with a neutral expression, pointed or floppy ears, and distinctive pig nose.

Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied üêñ Pig. Available as an Apple Animoji.

Apple’s face bears a slight grin and previously featured floppy ears.
components.title: Pig Face

description:
A friendly, cartoon-styled face of a pig looking straight ahead. Depicted as a pink face with a neutral expression, pointed or floppy ears, and distinctive pig nose.

Often used with a more affectionate tone than the full-bodied üêñ Pig. Available as an Apple Animoji.

title: Pig Face

version.description:
Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.

Some characters in prior versions of Unicode were retroactively updated to provide an emoji presentation. This release was the first to introduce new characters for the sole purpose of compatability with emojis being used in Japan.

emoji_net_data.category: Miscellaneous Symbols And Pictographs -> Animal faces

bn:00091155v: Utter a high-pitched cry, characteristic of pigs

bn:00056255n: Offspring of male donkey and female horse.
A generally sterile male or female hybrid offspring of a male donkey and a female horse.
Hybrid offspring of a male donkey and a female horse; usually sterile
A mule is the offspring of a male donkey and a female horse.
The offspring of a male donkey and a female horse.

bn:00062354n: Sus scrofa domestica or Sus domestica
A young female pig, at or nearing the age of first breeding.
The domestic pig, often called swine or hog, is a large, even-toed ungulate; it is variously considered a subspecies of the wild boar, or a distinct species.

bn:00042006n: Any of several mammalian species of the genus Sus, having cloven hooves, bristles and a nose adapted for digging; especially the domesticated farm animal Sus scrofa.
Animals in the genus Sus, within the Suidae family of even-toed ungulates
Pigs are ungulates native to Eurasia collectively grouped under the genus Sus within the Suidae family.
Sus scrofa domestica or Sus domestica
The domestic pig, often called swine or hog, is a large, even-toed ungulate; it is variously considered a subspecies of the wild boar, or a distinct species.
A common, four-legged animal (Sus scrofa) that has cloven hooves, bristles and a nose adapted for digging and is farmed by humans for its meat.
Any animal belonging to the Suidae family of mammals, especially the pig, the warthog, and the boar.
A pig is any of the animals in the genus Sus, within the Suidae family of even-toed ungulates.
